sub_title: Scrum Master (PSMII) bij Thermo Fisher Scientific via TMC
summary:
My name is Bart van Nieuwburg and I am Scrum Master (PSM2, SAFe5) and trainer. I love technology and my passion lies with working with people and teams.
 
As Scrum Master it gives me a lot of energy to help and coach teams. To help them to identify improvements and to help them removing their impediments. When I see a team grow from a group of individuals to a performing team that has fun together, it does not feel like going to work. 

As trainer I love to teach the thing that I love: good teamwork that leads to delivering (software) products of higher quality, faster and with a lot of fun along the way. My choice of framework to reach for that is Scrum.

Before I became Scrum Master I have built web and app solutions that support scientific research in the social sciences. I started the Agile transformation of the IT department by applying the Scrum framework. This made a great improvement in consistency, quality, development time and fun.

I like to read books and listen to podcasts to learn more about Agile and how people work together. I am SAFe5 certified and I have passed the PSMI & PSMII certification exam.

location.default: Loon op Zand, North Brabant, Netherlands

education.field_of_study: Informatica (Software engineering) / Hogere opleiding Software engineer

profile_positions.description:
Working at Thermo Fisher Scientific.
Worked at Philips.
Created and executed two day training courses on a full introduction to Scrum. As well as workshops about an introduction to Liberating Structures
profile_positions.title: Scrum Master & Trainer

profile_positions.description:
At Philips Healthcare I work with 3 DevOps Scrum teams in the Digital
Platform department. The teams are responsible for building several services in the
IoT Platform as well as several data stores. We work in a SAFe Scaled Agile environment with a highly regulated quality process.
profile_positions.title: Scrum Master via TMC Agile

profile_positions.description:
I have introduced the Scrum framework into the SHARE project (http://www.share-project.org) for the development of the software. The developers were situated in Tilburg and most stakeholders and testers were situated in the Max Planck Institute in Munich. This raised a communication barrier. My assignment was to improve communications and expectations between both parties. I saw the Scrum framework as a perfect fit. Together with the colleagues in Munich we figured out a way how Scrum could help us streamline the workflow of development and testing of the software. The backlog was maintained together and the sprint planning was communicated to the stakeholder. This helped in managing the expectations for all parties. The sprint planning made clear what was going to be finished after the next sprint. The transparency of a digital Scrum board helped the stakeholders to know what was being worked on at any given time.

SHARE is the Study of Health Ageing and Retirement conducted in 29 countries in Europe. Interviewers  conduct around 1.5 hour long offline interviews at the home of the respondents. The data is synchronised and transferred from the interviewers laptop to a servers in the country. Afterwards the data is transferred to a central server and it is checked. Finally the data is disemminated to scientists all around the world. 
Almost all software that is needed to conduct this project is developed by the programmers of CentERdata.
profile_positions.title: Scrum Master - SHARE Software Development

profile_positions.description:
As Scrum Master I have started the Agile transformation of the IT department of CentERdata. With the team we started our Agile journey by applying Scrum. I taught the Scrum Framework and Agile mindset to customers and colleagues in our internal and external organization. I trained and helped Product Owners in how to translate the wishes of the stakeholders into user stories that are ready to be developed. I coached Product Owners on how to maintain a product backlog, maximizing value. I organized code reviews for the developers so that they learned from each other's good and bad practices. 

Over the years the IT department had created a lot of software in many different programming languages and styles. There was a lot of legacy software that was being maintained. The Scrum team has re-written most of the software into a 'family of applications' called Data CTRL. We used re-usable modules to achieve sustainable maintenance. We implemented DevOps practices using GitLab to streamline the workflow. We continuously test the software against the OWASP top 10 security risks. 

While doing this we had to deal with the day-to-day ad-hoc work. To be able to meet the sprint goal while dealing with requests and interruptions, together with the team I implemented the Scrum pattern 'Illegitimus non interruptus'. 

In a short amount of time we have re-developed a large amount of software programs that our customers use daily in conducting their surveys. Some examples:

File Share - transferring files securely between parties. 
Digital Vault - Encrypted storing of data files for long term storage. 
SurveyCTRL - SaaS solution for researchers to conduct their surveys over a large group of respondents. 
Mass Mailer - A program to send e-mails to a large amount of receivers.
RepositoryCTRL - a data warehouse based on the DDI3 standard to search over large amounts of survey data. (https://www.dataarchive.lissdata.nl/)
Data Portal - A portal where researchers can download datasets.
profile_positions.title: Scrum Master

profile_positions.description:
The software of the LISS panel management system ran on PHP 5.6. It was my job to ensure that the software would run on PHP 7.2 and was tested. The panel mamangement system is being developed since 2007 and it has grown immensely big with a huge database and many code. 

We wrote a script that would go throug every line of code that would check for deprecated functions. The whole database layer had to be refactored and every database call had to be reprogrammed, checked and tested. We made a plan on how to make database changes to make it faster.

With a team of programmers we made an inventory of all the files and classes that needed to be checked. We programmed tests to ensure the results would be the same afterwards. We divided and executed the work. We checked progress and our experiences daily. We tested extensively. We made a plan to upgrade the system. And evenutally we went live with an updated panel management system that ws fully functional, refactored and tested.
profile_positions.title: Scrum master / project leader 'Refactoring panel management software'

profile_positions.description:
As Scientific Programmer I was responsible for developing and maintaining several applications around research in the Social Sciences. As senior scientific programmer my responsibilities included: Leading projects to completion, Programming Proofs of conceps, becoming involved in the hiring process of new personnel, visiting (inter)national conferences to present our work and occasionally organise a workshop. 

As scientific programmer my main responsibility was the development and maintenance of the software of the LISS panel. The LISS panel consists of >6.000 households that fill out monthly questionnaires. The LISS panel started in 2007. And many projects were conducted within the LISS panel that needed custom changes or external interfaces. E.g. weigh scales, accellerometers and SIM pc's were connected to the LISS panel.

For the SHARE project I have translated a JAVA application to online PHP so that exactly the same research could be conducted online. (2015-2016)

As PHP programmer I have developed many websites and webapplications in Drupal. One of the latest websites is the e-learning system for Math students joining Tilburg University: https://www.wiskundeoptiu.nl/

I have developed Proofs of concepts for solutions around data collection. I have developed an (web)app in AngularJS for coding variables (e.g. occupation and education) to internationally acknowledged codes https://www.surveycodings.org/survey-implementation/app
profile_positions.title: (Senior) Scientific Programmer

profile_positions.description: During my study I have developed websites and videopresentations for customers.
profile_positions.title: Owner

profile_positions.description: As my graduation internship I worked at Geodan to research the (at the time) fairly new Google Maps API for applicability. Together with another student I created a proof of concept that would later become the first 'store locator' for Albert Heijn.
profile_positions.title: Graduation Internship
